awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: DIMENSIONS: Secondary metabolites as drivers of fungal endophyte community diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants produce a diversity of chemicals that mediate they way they interact with other plants, with animals, and with beneficial and pathogenic microogranisms. There are often fungi associated with plants that can stimulate the production of and/or modify chemicals produced by the plant, or the fungi may produce the chemicals themselves. These chemicals can help determine plant resistance to disease and environmental stress. Many of the details of how plants promote beneficial fungi, and how fungi interact with one another to affect plant defenses are not known. The goals of this project are to better understand these details using coffee plants, their relatives, and the fungal microbiomes associated with different plant species.  Understanding the interactions of beneficial fungi in and on plant leaves will lead to improved strategies of disease management. Among the broader impacts of this project are botanical and microbial collections, and a database of plant and fungal genomic information that can serve as a resource for natural product discovery, and prevention and management of agricultural diseases. Additionally, students and postdocs will be trained in the various disciplines that are involved in this project, and an environmental genomics short course will be taught in two locations in the US and in Costa Rica.

This project will examine how secondary metabolites in foliar tissues define and are shaped by fungal endophyte communities, and how metabolite-defined niches and horizontal gene transfer of metabolic pathways promote species and genome diversity. Culture-dependent and culture-independent methods will be used to identify foliar endophyte communities associated with wild tropical Rubiaceae species, coffee plantation management strategies, and leaf metabolite profiles. Metabolomic analyses of leaves and endophyte competitive interactions will identify the roles of key fungi in the endophyte community and their contribution to the plant defense chemistry. Novel, genome-scale comparative analyses will identify gene clusters involved in the production and degradation of secondary metabolites, and the roles of these gene clusters in endophyte functional redundancy and fungal reproductive isolation will be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

A single plant leaf may contain hundreds of microbial species, including fungi. An extreme interpretation of this fact is that every intercellular space is occupied by endophytes (=microorganisms that live inside the tissues of plants without causing any visible negative impact) from different individuals, taxonomic, and functional groups. This creates a complex, mosaic environment entailing a rich continuum of antagonistic and synergistic interactions. These interactions may produce chemicals known as secondary metabolites. The project had as a major aim to understand the role endophytes and its symbiotic interactions play in the chemistry and health of the plant. We used coffee and the coffee family (Rubiaceae) as the study system. We collected hundreds of endophyte samples from natural tropical forests of Costa Rica, a Rubiaceae biodiversity hotspot. We first wanted to test the influence of various factors (e.g., secondary metabolites, geographic location, tissue type, leaf developmental stage, and coffee management regime) in fungal community composition. We found that only geographic distance and tissue type (leaf vs. sapwood) had an influence in the fungal diversity. We also found that endophyte diversity was different in planted organic vs. conventional coffee. Additional preliminary results and based on ongoing analyses, we found that chemical profiles and endophyte diversity (to a lesser extent) may be correlated to Rubiaceae subfamilies. We show that the endophytes living inside plant leaves, interact in a variety of ways, some being negative or antagonistic, others neutral (no effect), and many positive (beneficial), and those interactions may change the chemistry. An interesting example is the experiment where we confronted the endophyte Daldinia eschscholzii and the coffee pathogen Mycena citricolor to show that the volatile organic compounds in Daldinia alone or in confrontation with Mycena are significantly different. This suggests that only when the two fungi are interacting, specific VOCs are produced. Those VOCs are negatively affecting Mycena by "burning" its reproductive structures. Some of the VOCs found are known to have antifungal properties.

Broader impacts:

 With the basic knowledge on types of interactions between fungi and plants, we tested the effects these endophytes could have on the health of coffee plants. Coffee production is currently being threatened by climate change and diseases. Global consumer markets are presently demanding more environmentally friendly farming practices even when the transition from conventional agriculture may be challenging for the producing countries. Therefore, development of innovative and relatively cheap strategies that reduce economic losses and environmental impacts of pesticides/fungicides are pressing, as this crop is vital for the economies and cultures of many low-income countries. In this project, we inoculated endophytes in coffee seedlings to first test if these fungi colonized all the plant tissues and then if these endophytes provided benefits to the plant. We confirmed endophytic colonization in coffee plantlets, and showed that several fungi have potential for plant growth promotion (biofertilizer), and antagonism against Mycena and other seed and seedling pathogens (biofungicide), reducing incidence and severity, and preventing plant mortality. As a direct impact from this project, the farmers of the coffee cooperative in Costa Rica (Coopetarazu) have reduced the amount of fungicides by adding the endophytic fungi to their bioproducts. In addition, this project trained graduate and undergraduate students in the United States and Costa Rica in basic, applied, and integrative biology, learning from fieldwork, modern molecular tools, to applied agricultural sciences.
